title: Classification
text: article used benchmark evaluations obtained renoir classification problems external results.

title: Classification
text: Different public datasets already used classification problems considered: breast cancer data University Wisconsin Hospitals heart-disease data Cleveland Clinic Foundation Data retrieved UC Irvine Machine Learning Repository website.

title: Classification
text: Firstly, load renoir needed packages:
code: library(renoir) #> Warning: package 'Matrix' was built under R version 4.2.3 library(plotly) library(htmltools)

title: Classification
text: Now retrieve ids supported learners. list supported methods available ?list_supported_learning_methods function call. can extract ids selecting id column. table, can also see default hyperparameters methods. create default values, define function dispatch depending id input:
code: #list methods learning.methods = list_supported_learning_methods(x = "classification")  #print in table knitr::kable(x = learning.methods) #learning method ids learning.methods.ids = learning.methods$id #get hyperparameters get_hp = function(id, y){    #Generalised Linear Models with Penalisation   lambda = 10^seq(3, -2, length=100)   # alpha = seq(0.1, 0.9, length = 9)   alpha = seq(0.1, 0.9, length = 5)   gamma = c(0, 0.25, 0.5, 0.75, 1)      #Random Forest   ntree = c(10, 50, 100, 250, 500)      #Generalised Boosted Regression Modelling   eta = c(0.3, 0.1, 0.01, 0.001)      #Support Vector Machines   cost      = 2^seq(from = -5, to = 15, length.out = 5)   svm.gamma = 2^seq(from = -15, to = 3, length.out = 4)   degree    = seq(from = 1, to = 3, length.out = 3)   #Note that for classification nu must be   #nu * length(y)/2 <= min(table(y)). So instead of   #fixing it as   # nu        = seq(from = 0.1, to = 0.6, length.out = 5)   #we do   nu.to = floor((min(table(y)) * 2/length(y)) * 10) / 10   nu = seq(from = 0.1, to = nu.to, length.out = 5)      #kNN   k = seq(from = 1, to = 9, length.out = 5)    #Nearest Shrunken Centroid   threshold = seq(0, 2, length.out = 30)    #hyperparameters   out = switch(     id,     'lasso'              = list(lambda = lambda),     'ridge'              = list(lambda = lambda),     'elasticnet'         = list(lambda = lambda, alpha = alpha),     'relaxed_lasso'      = list(lambda = lambda, gamma = gamma),     'relaxed_ridge'      = list(lambda = lambda, gamma = gamma),     'relaxed_elasticnet' = list(lambda = lambda, gamma = gamma, alpha = alpha),     'randomForest'       = list(ntree = ntree),     'gbm'                = list(eta = eta, ntree = ntree),     'linear_SVM'         = list(cost = cost),     'polynomial_SVM'     = list(cost = cost, gamma = svm.gamma, degree = degree),     'radial_SVM'         = list(cost = cost, gamma = svm.gamma),     'sigmoid_SVM'        = list(cost = cost, gamma = svm.gamma),     'linear_NuSVM'       = list(nu = nu),     'polynomial_NuSVM'   = list(nu = nu, gamma = svm.gamma, degree = degree),     'radial_NuSVM'       = list(nu = nu, gamma = svm.gamma),     'sigmoid_NuSVM'      = list(nu = nu, gamma = svm.gamma),     'gknn'               = list(k = k),     'nsc'                = list(threshold = threshold)   )    return(out) }

title: Classification
text: list supported scoring metrics available ?list_supported_performance_metrics function call. benchmark want select accuracy precision, reported measure website.
code: #list metrics performance.metrics = list_supported_performance_metrics(resp.type = "binomial")  #print in table knitr::kable(x = performance.metrics) #metric for tuning performance.metric.id.tuning = "acc"  #metrics for evaluation performance.metric.ids.evaluation = c("acc", "precision")

title: Classification
text: list supported sampling methods available ?list_supported_sampling_methods function call. decided select common scenario stratified 10-fold cross-validation tuning hyperparameters, repeated random sampling evaluation methodology.
code: #list methods sampling.methods = list_supported_sampling_methods()  #print in table knitr::kable(x = sampling.methods) #sampling for tuning sampling.method.id.tuning = "cv"  #sampling for evaluation sampling.method.id.evaluation = "random"

title: Classification
text: can now run analyses.

title: Classification
text: Breast Cancer database University Wisconsin Hospitals retrieved UC Irvine Machine Learning Repository website.

title: Classification
text: load data. need set response type.
code: #load data load(file = file.path("..", "..", "data-raw", "benchmark", "classification", "bcwo", "data", "bcwo_data.rda")) #set response type resp.type = "binomial"

title: Classification
text: Now can create tuner performing grid.search via 10-fold cross-validation.
code: #tuner tuner = Tuner(   id = "grid.search",   sampler = Sampler(     method = sampling.method.id.tuning,     k = 10L,     n = integer(),     strata = y   ),   looper   = Looper(cores = 1L),   logger   = Logger(verbose = T, level = "INFO") )

title: Classification
text: can now create related ?Learner objects.
code: #container learners = list()  #loop for(learning.method.id in learning.methods.ids){   #manual setup   learners[[learning.method.id]] = Learner(     tuner      = tuner,     trainer    = Trainer(id = learning.method.id),     forecaster = Forecaster(id = learning.method.id),     scorer     = ScorerList(Scorer(id = performance.metric.id.tuning)),     selector   = Selector(id = learning.method.id),     recorder   = Recorder(id = learning.method.id),     marker     = Marker(id = learning.method.id),     logger     = Logger(level = "ALL")   ) }

title: Classification
text: Finally, need set ?Evaluator.
code: #Evaluator evaluator = Evaluator(   #Sampling strategy: stratified random sampling without replacement   sampler = Sampler(                    method = "random",                  k = 10L,                            strata = y,                         N = as.integer(length(y))         ),    #Performance metric   scorer  = ScorerList(     Scorer(id = performance.metric.ids.evaluation[1]),     Scorer(id = performance.metric.ids.evaluation[2])   ) )

title: Classification
text: Let’s create directory store results. running analysis, want set seed random number generation (RNG). fact, different R sessions different seeds created current time process ID default, consequently different simulation results. fixing seed ensure able reproduce results. can specify seed calling ?set.seed. code , set seed running analysis considered learning method.
code:
#define path outdir = file.path("..", "..", "data-raw", "benchmark", "classification", "bcwo", "analysis")  #create if not existing if(!dir.exists(outdir)){dir.create(path = outdir, showWarnings = F, recursive = T)} #container list resl = list()  #loop for(learning.method.id in learning.methods.ids){      #Each analysis can take hours, so we save data    #for future faster load      #path to file   fp.obj = file.path(outdir, paste0(learning.method.id,".rds"))   fp.sum = file.path(outdir, paste0("st_",learning.method.id,".rds"))      #check if exists   if(file.exists(fp.sum)){     #load     cat(paste0("Reading ", learning.method.id, "..."), sep = "")     resl[[learning.method.id]] = readRDS(file = fp.sum)     cat("DONE", sep = "
")   } else {        cat(paste("Learning method:", learning.method.id), sep = "
")          #Set a seed for RNG     set.seed(       #A seed       seed = 5381L,                   #a randomly chosen integer value       #The kind of RNG to use       kind = "Mersenne-Twister",      #we make explicit the current R default value       #The kind of Normal generation       normal.kind = "Inversion"       #we make explicit the current R default value     )          resl[[learning.method.id]] = renoir(       # filter,          #Training set size       npoints = 5,       # ngrid,       nmin = round(nrow(x)/2),          #Loop       looper = Looper(),          #Store       filename = "renoir",       outdir   = NULL,       restore  = TRUE,          #Learn       learner   = learners[[learning.method.id]],          #Evaluate       evaluator = evaluator,          #Log       logger    = Logger(level = "ALL", verbose = T),          #Data for training       hyperparameters = get_hp(id = learning.method.id, y = y),       x         = x,       y         = y,       weights   = NULL,       offset    = NULL,       resp.type = resp.type,          #Free space       rm.call = FALSE,       rm.fit  = FALSE,          #Group results       grouping = TRUE,          #No screening       screening = NULL,              #Remove call from trainer to reduce space       keep.call = F     )          #save obj     saveRDS(object = resl[[learning.method.id]], file = fp.obj)          #create summary table     resl[[learning.method.id]] = renoir:::summary_table.RenoirList(resl[[learning.method.id]], key = c("id", "config"))          #save summary table     saveRDS(object = resl[[learning.method.id]], file = fp.sum)          cat("

", sep = "
")   } }  #create summary table resl = do.call(what = rbind, args = c(resl, make.row.names = F, stringsAsFactors = F))

title: Classification
text: precision score opt configuration considering train set. precision score 1se configuration considering train set.
code: #plot renoir:::plot.RenoirSummaryTable(   x = resl[resl$config == "opt",,drop=F],   measure     = "precision",    set         = "train",    interactive = T,    add.boxplot = F,   add.scores  = F,   add.best    = F,   key         = c("id", "config")   ) #> Warning in RColorBrewer::brewer.pal(N, "Set2"): n too large, allowed maximum for palette Set2 is 8 #> Returning the palette you asked for with that many colors  #> Warning in RColorBrewer::brewer.pal(N, "Set2"): n too large, allowed maximum for palette Set2 is 8 #> Returning the palette you asked for with that many colors #plot renoir:::plot.RenoirSummaryTable(   x = resl[resl$config == "1se",,drop=F], #select 1se config    measure     = "precision",    set         = "train",    interactive = T,    add.boxplot = F,   add.scores  = F,   add.best    = F,   key         = c("id", "config")   ) #> Warning in RColorBrewer::brewer.pal(N, "Set2"): n too large, allowed maximum for palette Set2 is 8 #> Returning the palette you asked for with that many colors  #> Warning in RColorBrewer::brewer.pal(N, "Set2"): n too large, allowed maximum for palette Set2 is 8 #> Returning the palette you asked for with that many colors

title: Regression
text: article used benchmark evaluations obtained renoir regression problems external results.

title: Regression
text: Different public datasets already used regression problems considered: relative CPU Performance data Ein-Dor Feldmesser [1987] city-cycle fuel consumption data Carnegie Mellon University Statistics library Data retrieved UC Irvine Machine Learning Repository website.

title: Regression
text: Firstly, load renoir needed packages:
code: library(renoir) #> Warning: package 'Matrix' was built under R version 4.2.3 library(plotly) library(htmltools)

title: Regression
text: Now retrieve ids supported learners supporting regression problems. list supported methods available ?list_supported_learning_methods function call. can extract ids selecting id column. table, can also see default hyperparameters methods. create default values, define function dispatch depending id input:
code: #list methods learning.methods = list_supported_learning_methods(x = "regression")  #print in table knitr::kable(x = learning.methods) #learning method ids learning.methods.ids = learning.methods$id #get hyperparameters get_hp = function(id){      #Generalised Linear Models with Penalisation   lambda = 10^seq(3, -2, length=100)   # alpha = seq(0.1, 0.9, length = 9)   alpha = seq(0.1, 0.9, length = 5)   gamma = c(0, 0.25, 0.5, 0.75, 1)      #Random Forest   ntree = c(10, 50, 100, 250, 500)      #Generalised Boosted Regression Modelling   eta = c(0.3, 0.1, 0.01, 0.001)    #Support Vector Machines   cost      = 2^seq(from = -5, to = 15, length.out = 5)   svm.gamma = 2^seq(from = -15, to = 3, length.out = 4)   degree    = seq(from = 1, to = 3, length.out = 3)   nu        = seq(from = 0.1, to = 0.6, length.out = 6)      #kNN   k = seq(from = 1, to = 9, length.out = 5)    #hyperparameters   out = switch(     id,     'lasso'              = list(lambda = lambda),     'ridge'              = list(lambda = lambda),     'elasticnet'         = list(lambda = lambda, alpha = alpha),     'relaxed_lasso'      = list(lambda = lambda, gamma = gamma),     'relaxed_ridge'      = list(lambda = lambda, gamma = gamma),     'relaxed_elasticnet' = list(lambda = lambda, gamma = gamma, alpha = alpha),     'randomForest'       = list(ntree = ntree),     'gbm'                = list(eta = eta, ntree = ntree),     'linear_SVM'         = list(cost = cost),     'polynomial_SVM'     = list(cost = cost, gamma = svm.gamma, degree = degree),     'radial_SVM'         = list(cost = cost, gamma = svm.gamma),     'sigmoid_SVM'        = list(cost = cost, gamma = svm.gamma),     'linear_NuSVM'       = list(nu = nu),     'polynomial_NuSVM'   = list(nu = nu, gamma = svm.gamma, degree = degree),     'radial_NuSVM'       = list(nu = nu, gamma = svm.gamma),     'sigmoid_NuSVM'      = list(nu = nu, gamma = svm.gamma),     'gknn'               = list(k = k)   )      return(out) }

title: Regression
text: list supported scoring metrics available ?list_supported_performance_metrics function call. benchmark want select mean absolute error mean squared error.
code: #list metrics performance.metrics = list_supported_performance_metrics(resp.type = "gaussian")  #print in table knitr::kable(x = performance.metrics) #metric for tuning performance.metric.id.tuning = "mse"  #metrics for evaluation performance.metric.ids.evaluation = c("mae", "mse")

title: Regression
text: list supported sampling methods available ?list_supported_sampling_methods function call. decided select common scenario stratified 10-fold cross-validation tuning hyperparameters, repeated random sampling evaluation methodology.
code: #list methods sampling.methods = list_supported_sampling_methods()  #print in table knitr::kable(x = sampling.methods) #sampling for tuning sampling.method.id.tuning = "cv"  #sampling for evaluation sampling.method.id.evaluation = "random"

title: Regression
text: can now run analyses.

title: Regression
text: relative CPU Performance data retrieved UC Irvine Machine Learning Repository website.

title: Regression
text: load data. need set response type.
code: #load data load(file = file.path("..", "..", "data-raw", "benchmark", "regression", "gaussian", "cpu", "data", "cpu_data.rda")) #set response type resp.type = "gaussian"

title: Regression
text: Now can create tuner performing grid.search via 10-fold cross-validation.
code: #tuner tuner = Tuner(   id = "grid.search",   sampler = Sampler(     method = sampling.method.id.tuning,     k = 10L,     n = integer()   ),   looper   = Looper(cores = 1L),   logger   = Logger(verbose = T, level = "INFO") )

title: Regression
text: can now create related ?Learner objects.
code: #container learners = list()  #loop for(learning.method.id in learning.methods.ids){   #manual setup   learners[[learning.method.id]] = Learner(     tuner      = tuner,     trainer    = Trainer(id = learning.method.id),     forecaster = Forecaster(id = learning.method.id),     scorer     = ScorerList(Scorer(id = performance.metric.id.tuning)),     selector   = Selector(id = learning.method.id),     recorder   = Recorder(id = learning.method.id, logger = Logger(level = "ALL", verbose = T)),     marker     = Marker(id = learning.method.id, logger = Logger(level = "ALL", verbose = T)),     logger     = Logger(level = "ALL")   ) }

title: Regression
text: Finally, need set ?Evaluator.
code: #Evaluator evaluator = Evaluator(   #Sampling strategy: random sampling without replacement   sampler = Sampler(                    method = "random",                  k = 10L,                            N = as.integer(length(y))         ),    #Performance metric   scorer  = ScorerList(     Scorer(id = performance.metric.ids.evaluation[1]),     Scorer(id = performance.metric.ids.evaluation[2])   ) )

title: Regression
text: Let’s create directory store results. running analysis, want set seed random number generation (RNG). fact, different R sessions different seeds created current time process ID default, consequently different simulation results. fixing seed ensure able reproduce results. can specify seed calling ?set.seed. code , set seed running analysis considered learning method.
code:
#define path outdir = file.path("..", "..", "data-raw", "benchmark", "regression", "gaussian", "cpu", "analysis")  #create if not existing if(!dir.exists(outdir)){dir.create(path = outdir, showWarnings = F, recursive = T)} #container list resl = list()  #loop for(learning.method.id in learning.methods.ids){      #Each analysis can take hours, so we save data    #for future faster load      #path to file   fp.obj = file.path(outdir, paste0(learning.method.id,".rds"))   fp.sum = file.path(outdir, paste0("st_",learning.method.id,".rds"))      #check if exists   if(file.exists(fp.sum)){     #load     cat(paste0("Reading ", learning.method.id, "..."), sep = "")     resl[[learning.method.id]] = readRDS(file = fp.sum)     cat("DONE", sep = "
")   } else {        cat(paste("Learning method:", learning.method.id), sep = "
")          #Set a seed for RNG     set.seed(       #A seed       seed = 5381L,                   #a randomly chosen integer value       #The kind of RNG to use       kind = "Mersenne-Twister",      #we make explicit the current R default value       #The kind of Normal generation       normal.kind = "Inversion"       #we make explicit the current R default value     )          resl[[learning.method.id]] = renoir(       # filter,          #Training set size       npoints = 5,       # ngrid,       nmin = round(nrow(x)/2),          #Loop       looper = Looper(),          #Store       filename = "renoir",       outdir   = NULL,       restore  = TRUE,          #Learn       learner   = learners[[learning.method.id]],          #Evaluate       evaluator = evaluator,          #Log       logger    = Logger(level = "ALL", verbose = T),          #Data for training       hyperparameters = get_hp(id = learning.method.id),       x         = x,       y         = y,       weights   = NULL,       offset    = NULL,       resp.type = resp.type,          #Free space       rm.call = FALSE,       rm.fit  = FALSE,          #Group results       grouping = TRUE,          #No screening       screening = NULL,              #Remove call from trainer to reduce space       keep.call = F     )          #save obj     saveRDS(object = resl[[learning.method.id]], file = fp.obj)          #create summary table     resl[[learning.method.id]] = renoir:::summary_table.RenoirList(resl[[learning.method.id]], key = c("id", "config"))          #save summary table     saveRDS(object = resl[[learning.method.id]], file = fp.sum)          #leave space     cat("

", sep= "
")   } }  #create summary table resl = do.call(what = rbind, args = c(resl, make.row.names = F, stringsAsFactors = F))

title: An introduction to `renoir`
text: renoir package evaluates chosen machine learning methodology via multiple random sampling approach spanning different training-set sizes. renoir developed thinking teaching/learning abstraction. two main actors renoir framework: learner, evaluator. learner represents learning method assessment linked ?Learner class. evaluator responsible evaluation procedure, .e. assessment performance learner via multiple random sampling, related ?Evaluator class. example Quick Start help familiarizing concepts.

title: An introduction to `renoir`
text: section briefly go main functions, basic operations outputs. First, load renoir package: brief example, decided show functionality renoir classification problem. Let us load set data illustration: command loads input matrix x response vector y saved R data archive. Now want set seed random number generation (RNG). fact, different R sessions different seeds created current time process ID default, consequently different simulation results. fixing seed ensure able reproduce results example. can specify seed calling ?set.seed. reported Introduction, main actors renoir ?Learner ?Evaluator classes, also main elements need set running analysis.
code: library(renoir) #> Warning: package 'Matrix' was built under R version 4.2.3 data(binomial_example) #Set a seed for RNG set.seed(   #A seed   seed = 5381L,                   #a randomly chosen integer value   #The kind of RNG to use   kind = "Mersenne-Twister",      #we make explicit the current R default value   #The kind of Normal generation   normal.kind = "Inversion"       #we make explicit the current R default value )

title: An introduction to `renoir`
text: Let us start ?Learner. ?Learner container different essential elements learning methodology want evaluate. example, focus just three elements, .e. learning procedure, sampling approach, performance metric. first step, need select learning methodology evaluate. list supported methods available ?list_supported_learning_methods function call. example, choose generalized linear model via L1 penalty (lasso) learning method. table, can see default hyperparameter method lambda.
code: #list methods learning.methods = list_supported_learning_methods()  #print in table knitr::kable(x = learning.methods)

title: An introduction to `renoir`
text: Now want select sampling procedure use tuning hyperparameter. list supported sampling methods available ?list_supported_sampling_methods function call. can see renoir currently supports three sampling scheme: random sampling without replacement, cross-validation. provide options stratified approach, -called ‘proportionate allocation’ attempted maintain proportion strata samples population. hand, random sampling bootstrap allow balancing, meaning proportion strata sample attempted balanced. example, decided tune parameter via stratified 10-fold cross-validation.
code: #list methods sampling.methods = list_supported_sampling_methods()  #print in table knitr::kable(x = sampling.methods)

title: An introduction to `renoir`
text: Finally, want choose performance metric assess models tuning. list supported scoring metrics available ?list_supported_performance_metrics function call. can see ?list_supported_performance_metrics function reported performance metrics regression classification problems. Let us refine search listing supported metrics binomial response type . can providing resp.type argument function shown . expected, now metrics classification problems listed. Let us select misclassification error (also called classification error rate) performance metric. , overall want train model lasso, tuning hyperparameter lambda via 10-fold cross-validation using misclassification error assess performance models.
code: #list metrics performance.metrics = list_supported_performance_metrics()  #print in table knitr::kable(x = performance.metrics) #list metrics performance.metrics = list_supported_performance_metrics(resp.type = "binomial")  #print in table knitr::kable(x = performance.metrics)

title: An introduction to `renoir`
text: Since lasso renoir built-method, can create related ?Learner object single command. used simplified interface constructor, internally creating different needed elements. want fine-grained setting can use alternative interface shown . going details example, however note sampling procedure set creating object class ?Sampler, object class ?Scorer can used define performance metric.
code: #Learner learner <- Learner(   #Learning method   id        = "lasso",    #generalised linear model with penalization   #Response type   resp.type = "binomial",   #Sampling strategy   strata    = y,          #by providing a strata we select the stratified approach   sampling  = "cv",       #cross-validation   k         = 10L,        #10-fold   #Performance metric   score     = "class"     #classification error rate ) #Learner learner <- Learner(   #Trainer   trainer = Trainer(id = "lasso"),   #generalised linear model with penalization      #Tuner   tuner = Tuner(     sampler = Sampler(               #A Sampler contains info for the sampling strategy        method = "cv",                 #cross-validation       k = 10L,                       #10-fold       strata = y                     #by providing a strata we select the stratified approach     )   ),      #Predictor   forecaster = Forecaster(id = "lasso"),      #Performance metric   scorer     = Scorer(                    id = "class",                    #classification error rate     resp.type = "binomial"),      #Select one model from a list   selector   = Selector(id = "lasso"),      #Record features presence in a model   recorder   = Recorder(id = "lasso"),      #Assign a mark to each feature   marker     = Marker(id = "lasso") )

title: An introduction to `renoir`
text: Now need set ?Evaluator. Objects class contains infrastructure evaluation procedure, mainly consists sampling strategy adopt metric compute estimate learning method performance. can easily set sampling strategy performance metric creating objects class ?Sampler ?Scorer, respectively shown .
code: #Evaluator evaluator = Evaluator(   #Sampling strategy: stratified random sampling without replacement   sampler = Sampler(               #Sampler object     method = "random",             #random sampling without replacement     k = 10L,                        #k repeats     strata = y,                    #stratified     N = as.integer(length(y))      #population size   ),    #Performance metric   scorer  = Scorer(id = "class"), )

title: An introduction to `renoir`
text: Now main actors set, can run analysis. renoir provides single command purpose, ?renoir function. essential required elements ?Learner, ?Evaluator, predictor matrix x, response variable y, response type resp.type. Since chosen learning method one hyperparameter (lambda), also need provide hyperparameters element, supply sequence values used tuning model.
code: #Renoir renoirl = renoir(   #Learn   learner   = learner,                  #a Learner object    #Evaluate   evaluator = evaluator,                #an Evaluator object    #Data for tuning   hyperparameters = list(               #the hyperparameter we     lambda = 10^seq(3, -2, length=100)  #want to tune (for the   ),                                    #lasso is lambda)      #Data for training   x         = x,                        #the predictor matrix   y         = y,                        #the response variable   resp.type = "binomial"                #the response type )

title: An introduction to `renoir`
text: renoirl list containing two elements class ?Renoir, providing relevant information evaluation procedure. two elements renoir tries select two different final configurations tuning procedure: one configuration (called opt) configuration mean performance chosen repeated sampling procedure optimum value compared across others, e.g. configuration minimal classification error rate; (called 1SE) configuration resulting application -called one standard error rule consists selecting parsimonious model mean performance within one standard error optimum.

title: An introduction to `renoir`
text: Various methods provided ?Renoir object. example, can produce summary data.frame containing evaluation lasso across different training-set sizes executing ?summary_table command:
code: #get the summary s = summary_table(object = renoirl[[1]])  #print in table DT::datatable(   data = s,                  #data to table   rownames           = F,    #don't show row names   options = list(                lengthMenu = list(       #length of the menu       c(3, 5, 10),           #set 3 as the minimum        c(3, 5, 10)),          #number of shown entries     scrollX = T),            #enable horizontal scrolling   width = "100%",            #width size   height = "auto"            #height size )

title: An introduction to `renoir`
text: can also visualize results executing ?plot function. example, let us plot results evaluation considering full set data:  circle corresponds performance trained model. mean performance metric (.e. mean misclassification error) computed model performance scores training-set size shown orange line, related confidence intervals drawn bands around mean. red square represents overall best model selected via internal procedure: example, considering misclassification error, renoir selects potential best model choosing model minimal score across models fitted using training-set size showing lowest upper bound 95% CI. example, plot shows quite constant mean score around 0.03 across training-set sizes, indicating good performance classifier. facilitate inspection results, also possible produce interactive plot setting argument interactive = TRUE ?plot command. plot can now zoomed selecting area:  information also shown hoovering plot element. example, try hoover red dot representing best model able see something like :  top row indicates position x y axes: selected model training-set size 681 misclassification error 0.029. Please, note circles slightly jittered position clearer plot, values reported hoovering correct. second row reporting iteration index corresponding model: case, 4th model trained repeated sampling procedure selected best model. supervised screening performed, model contains 9 features. Finally, value lambda resulted tuning used train final model reported.
code: plot(x = renoirl[[1]], measure = "class", set = "full") plot(x = renoirl[[1]], measure = "class", set = "full", interactive = TRUE)

title: Use Case
text: article provides use case renoir.

title: Use Case
text: considered data accompanying paper Sakellaropoulos et al., made available link: batch-normalized GDSC/bortezomib dataset clinical response data Samples information clinical data provided supplementary material.

title: Use Case
text: Firstly, load renoir needed packages:
code: library(renoir) #> Warning: package 'Matrix' was built under R version 4.2.3 library(plotly) library(htmltools)

title: Use Case
text: Given high dimensional data, want apply initial step pre-processing sub-setting features space. list supported methods available ?list_supported_unsupervised_screening_methods function call. decided reduce dimensionality selecting top variable features.
code: #list methods u.screening.methods = list_supported_unsupervised_screening_methods()  #print in table knitr::kable(x = u.screening.methods) #method id u.screening.method.id = "variability"

title: Use Case
text: Now retrieve ids supported learners. list supported methods available ?list_supported_learning_methods function call. can extract ids selecting id column. use case decided focus methods. table, can also see default hyperparameters methods. create default values, define function dispatch depending id input:
code: #list methods learning.methods = list_supported_learning_methods()  #print in table knitr::kable(x = learning.methods) #learning method ids learning.methods.ids = learning.methods$id[c(1,2,3,7)] #get hyperparameters get_hp = function(id, y){    #Generalised Linear Models with Penalisation   lambda = 10^seq(3, -2, length=100)   # alpha = seq(0.1, 0.9, length = 9)   # alpha = seq(0.1, 0.9, length = 5)   alpha = seq(0.05, 0.95, by = 0.05)^2   gamma = c(0, 0.25, 0.5, 0.75, 1)      #Random Forest   ntree = c(100, 500, 1000)      #Generalised Boosted Regression Modelling   eta = c(0.3, 0.1, 0.01, 0.001)      #Support Vector Machines   cost      = 2^seq(from = -5, to = 15, length.out = 5)   svm.gamma = 2^seq(from = -15, to = 3, length.out = 4)   degree    = seq(from = 1, to = 3, length.out = 3)   #Note that for classification nu must be   #nu * length(y)/2 <= min(table(y)). So instead of   #fixing it as   # nu        = seq(from = 0.1, to = 0.6, length.out = 5)   #we do   nu.to = floor((min(table(y)) * 2/length(y)) * 10) / 10   nu = seq(from = 0.1, to = nu.to, length.out = 5)      #kNN   k = seq(from = 1, to = 9, length.out = 5)    #Nearest Shrunken Centroid   threshold = seq(0, 2, length.out = 30)    #hyperparameters   out = switch(     id,     'lasso'              = list(lambda = lambda),     'ridge'              = list(lambda = lambda),     'elasticnet'         = list(lambda = lambda, alpha = alpha),     'relaxed_lasso'      = list(lambda = lambda, gamma = gamma),     'relaxed_ridge'      = list(lambda = lambda, gamma = gamma),     'relaxed_elasticnet' = list(lambda = lambda, gamma = gamma, alpha = alpha),     'randomForest'       = list(ntree = ntree),     'gbm'                = list(eta = eta, ntree = ntree),     'linear_SVM'         = list(cost = cost),     'polynomial_SVM'     = list(cost = cost, gamma = svm.gamma, degree = degree),     'radial_SVM'         = list(cost = cost, gamma = svm.gamma),     'sigmoid_SVM'        = list(cost = cost, gamma = svm.gamma),     'linear_NuSVM'       = list(nu = nu),     'polynomial_NuSVM'   = list(nu = nu, gamma = svm.gamma, degree = degree),     'radial_NuSVM'       = list(nu = nu, gamma = svm.gamma),     'sigmoid_NuSVM'      = list(nu = nu, gamma = svm.gamma),     'gknn'               = list(k = k),     'nsc'                = list(threshold = threshold)   )    return(out) }

title: Use Case
text: list supported scoring metrics available ?list_supported_performance_metrics function call. benchmark want select mean absolute error mean squared error.
code: #list metrics performance.metrics = list_supported_performance_metrics(resp.type = "gaussian")  #print in table knitr::kable(x = performance.metrics) #metric for tuning performance.metric.id.tuning = "mse"  #metrics for evaluation performance.metric.ids.evaluation = c("mae", "mse")

title: Use Case
text: list supported sampling methods available ?list_supported_sampling_methods function call. decided select common scenario stratified k-fold cross-validation tuning hyperparameters, repeated random sampling evaluation methodology. can see high-dimensional settings, number variables >> number observations. reduce noise associated settings (computational time) can apply initial unsupervised screening step. Moreover, can also take advantage supervised screening step training.
code: #list methods sampling.methods = list_supported_sampling_methods()  #print in table knitr::kable(x = sampling.methods) #sampling for tuning sampling.method.id.tuning = "cv"  #sampling for evaluation sampling.method.id.evaluation = "random"

title: Use Case
text: can now run analyses.

title: Use Case
text: need set response type.
code: #path fp = file.path("..", "..", "data-raw", "use_case", "cell_lines", "data")  #load data x = readRDS(file = file.path(fp, "bortezomib_cells.rds"))  #process y = stats::setNames(object = x$Bortezomib, nm = rownames(x)) x = as.matrix(x[,-1])  #remove data without response y = y[!is.na(y)] x = x[names(y),]  #inspect predictors matrix cat(paste("Number of features:", ncol(x)), sep = "\n") cat(paste("Number of observations:", nrow(x)), sep = "\n") #set response type resp.type = "gaussian"

title: Use Case
text: Firstly, want setup filter reduce dimensionality problem. provide Filter object ?renoir function call, can perform unsupervised screening separately using ?filter function.
code: top.genes = c(0.2, 0.8, 0.9, 1)[2]  #filter uscreener = Filter(   #id of the method   id = u.screening.method.id,   #fix some arguments   parameters = list(       threshold = top.genes, #select features in the top 25\%     method    = "mad"  #use standard deviation to measure variability   ),   #logger   logger   = Logger(verbose = T, level = "INFO") ) #unsupervised screening filtered = renoir::filter(   filter = uscreener,   x = x )  #get x x.sub = filtered@filtered

title: Use Case
text: setup supervised screener adopt tuning.
code: #screener screener = Screener(   #id of the method   id = "ebayes",   #fix some arguments   parameters = list(       p.value = 0.05,    #select features with p < 0.05     logged2 = F,    #data was logged     assay.type = 'array' #applies limma-trend method   ),   #logger   logger   = Logger(verbose = T, level = "INFO") )

title: Use Case
text: Now can create tuner performing grid.search via 5-fold cross-validation.
code: #tuner tuner = Tuner(   id = "grid.search",   #Sampling strategy   sampler = Sampler(     method = sampling.method.id.tuning,     k = 5L,     n = integer()     # ,strata = y   ),   #   screener = ScreenerList(screener),   #Use parallel   looper   = Looper(cores = 1L),   #Logger   logger   = Logger(verbose = T, level = "INFO")   # logger   = Logger(verbose = T, level = "DEBUG") )

title: Use Case
text: can now create related ?Learner objects.
code: #container learners = list()  #loop for(learning.method.id in learning.methods.ids){   #manual setup   learners[[learning.method.id]] = Learner(     tuner      = tuner,     trainer    = Trainer(id = learning.method.id),     forecaster = Forecaster(id = learning.method.id),     scorer     = ScorerList(Scorer(id = performance.metric.id.tuning)),     selector   = Selector(id = learning.method.id),     recorder   = Recorder(id = learning.method.id, logger = Logger(level = "ALL", verbose = T)),     marker     = Marker(id = learning.method.id, logger = Logger(level = "ALL", verbose = T)),     logger     = Logger(level = "ALL")   ) }

title: Use Case
text: Finally, need set ?Evaluator.
code: #Evaluator evaluator = Evaluator(   #Sampling strategy: stratified random sampling without replacement   sampler = Sampler(                    method = "random",                  k = 10L,                            # strata = y,                         N = as.integer(length(y))         ),    #Performance metric   scorer  = ScorerList(     Scorer(id = performance.metric.ids.evaluation[1]),     Scorer(id = performance.metric.ids.evaluation[2])     # Scorer(id = performance.metric.ids.evaluation[3])   ) )

title: Use Case
text: Let’s create directory store results. Now can run analysis. running analysis, want set seed random number generation (RNG). fact, different R sessions different seeds created current time process ID default, consequently different simulation results. fixing seed ensure able reproduce results. can specify seed calling ?set.seed. code , set seed running analysis considered learning method.
code:
#define path outdir = file.path("E:", "Personal", "My Software", "R packages", "renoir", "data-raw", "use_case", "cell_lines", "analysis", "bortezomib", paste0("top",top.genes*100)) outdir = file.path("..", "..", "data-raw", "use_case", "cell_lines", "analysis", "bortezomib", paste0("top",top.genes*100))  #create if not existing if(!dir.exists(outdir)){dir.create(path = outdir, showWarnings = F, recursive = T)} #container list resl = list()  #loop # learning.method.id = learning.methods.ids[2] for(learning.method.id in learning.methods.ids){      #Each analysis can take hours, so we save data    #for future faster load      #path to file   fp.obj = file.path(outdir, paste0(learning.method.id,".rds"))   fp.sum = file.path(outdir, paste0("st_",learning.method.id,".rds"))      #check if exists   if(file.exists(fp.sum)){     #load     cat(paste("Reading", learning.method.id, "..."), sep = "")     resl[[learning.method.id]] = readRDS(file = fp.sum)     cat("DONE", sep = "
")   } else {        cat(paste("Learning method:", learning.method.id), sep = "
")          #Set a seed for RNG     set.seed(       #A seed       seed = 5381L,                   #a randomly chosen integer value       #The kind of RNG to use       kind = "Mersenne-Twister",      #we make explicit the current R default value       #The kind of Normal generation       normal.kind = "Inversion"       #we make explicit the current R default value     )          resl[[learning.method.id]] = renoir(       #Unsupervised screening       # filter = filter,          #Training set size       npoints = 3,       # ngrid,       nmin = round(nrow(x)/2),          #Loop       looper = Looper(),          #Store       filename = "renoir",       outdir   = file.path(outdir, learning.method.id),       restore  = TRUE,          #Learn       learner   = learners[[learning.method.id]],          #Evaluate       evaluator = evaluator,          #Log       logger    = Logger(         path = file.path(outdir, learning.method.id, "log.txt"),         level = "ALL",          verbose = T),          #Data for training       hyperparameters = get_hp(id = learning.method.id, y = y),       # x         = x,       x         = x.sub,       y         = y,       weights   = NULL,       offset    = NULL,       resp.type = resp.type,          #space       rm.call = T,       rm.fit  = T,          #Group results       grouping = TRUE,          #No screening       # screening = c(500, 1000, 2358),       screening = NULL,              #Remove call from trainer to reduce space       keep.call = F     )          #save     saveRDS(object = resl[[learning.method.id]], file = fp.obj)          #create summary table     resl[[learning.method.id]] = renoir:::summary_table.RenoirList(resl[[learning.method.id]], key = c("id", "config"))          #save summary table     saveRDS(object = resl[[learning.method.id]], file = fp.sum)          cat("

", sep = "
")   } }  #create summary table resl = do.call(what = rbind, args = c(resl, make.row.names = F, stringsAsFactors = F))

code:
#set colors col.lasso = "rgba(255, 127,  14, 1)" col.ridge = "rgba(140,  86,  75, 1)" col.elnet = "rgba( 23, 190, 207, 1)" col.rndfr = "rgba(214,  39,  40, 1)"  col.list = list(lasso = col.lasso, ridge = col.ridge, elasticnet = col.elnet, randomForest = col.rndfr)  #list to store data outl = list()  #lasso learning.method.id = 'lasso' for(set in c("train", "test", "full")){   title = switch(     set,     "train" = "Train set",      "test" = "Test set",      "full" = "Full set"   )   #create and store   outl[[set]][[learning.method.id]] = renoir:::plot.RenoirSummaryTable(       x = resl[resl$config == "opt" & resl$learning == learning.method.id,,drop=F],       measure = "mse",       name.ms = paste0("mean score
", learning.method.id),       set = "train",       interactive = T,       add.boxplot = T,       add.scores = T,       add.best = T,       key = c("id", "config"),       colour = col.list[[learning.method.id]]     ) %>% layout(yaxis = list(title = title)) }   for(set in c("train", "test", "full")){   title = switch(     set,     "train" = "Train set",      "test" = "Test set",      "full" = "Full set"   )   for(learning.method.id in learning.methods.ids[2:4]){     #create     #store     outl[[set]][[learning.method.id]] = renoir:::plot.RenoirSummaryTable(       x = resl[resl$config == "opt" & resl$learning == learning.method.id,,drop=F],       measure = "mse",       name.ms = paste0("mean score
", learning.method.id),       set = set,       interactive = T,       add.boxplot = T,       add.scores = T,       add.best = T,       key = c("id", "config"),       colour = col.list[[learning.method.id]]     ) # %>% plotly::layout(yaxis = list(title = paste0('Mean-squared Error
', title)))   } }  fig <- plotly::subplot(   unlist(outl, recursive = FALSE),    nrows = 3,    titleY = TRUE,   titleX = FALSE,   shareY = TRUE,   shareX = TRUE )  #layout finalfig = fig %>% plotly::layout(margin = list(l = 75, r = 25, b = 50, t = 50))  finalfig = finalfig %>% plotly::layout(   annotations = list(     list(       x = 0,        y = 0.5,        text = "Mean-squared Error",       xshift = -75,       font = list(color = "black",size = 14),       textangle = 270,       showarrow = F,        xref='paper',        yref='paper',        size=48),     list(       x = 0.5,        y = 0,        text = "Trainig-set size",       yshift = -50,       font = list(color = "black",size = 14),       showarrow = F,        xref='paper',        yref='paper',        size=48)   ) )

title: REsampliNg methOds for machIne leaRning
text: renoir R package providing analytical framework robust reproducible machine learning analyses. idea behind renoir implement scalable, modular open-source software standardised application machine learning techniques high-dimensional data.  renoir allows robust estimation true error learning methodology implementing multiple random-sampling approach spanning different training-set sizes, computing mean performance metrics confidence intervals. Appropriate unsupervised pre-processing strategies initial dimensionality reduction integrated facilitate correct application part process. considered train-set size, evaluation learning methodology based training testing models multiple independent train/test sets data generated via random sampling, bootstrapping k-fold cross-validation, training set used build models, left-set assess performance. computed measures assessment used obtain estimate mean performance related 95% confidence interval. Different supervised feature screening strategies implemented incorporated learning steps, .e. training/tuning models. Regression classification problems binomial data currently supported.

text: Install latest development version GitHub (requires devtools package):
code: if (!require("devtools")) {   install.packages("devtools") } devtools::install_github(   repo = "alebarberis/renoir",    dependencies = TRUE,    build_vignettes = FALSE )

title:
Forecaster Class
An S4 class providing the methods to test the trained models on provided data. — Forecaster-class
text: id object identifier, must equivalent id associated Trainer. learning method one supported renoir, constructor automatically select forecaster selector missing. forecaster (optional) function used compute predictions. Used id one supported renoir. forecaster provided must conform renoir common interface, must following formal arguments: object model prediction desired. Trained object returned training process, fit stored fit slot newx new values prediction made type type prediction required newoffset offset used fit one must provided ... additional arguments affecting predictions produced selector (optional) helper function select appropriate prediction type given response type accuracy measure provided must return prediction type supported forecaster must following formal arguments: resp.type response type type.measure accuracy type measure, used internally select correct prediction type

Trained object returned training process, fit stored fit slot newx new values prediction made type type prediction required newoffset offset used fit one must provided ... additional arguments affecting predictions produced selector helper function select appropriate prediction type given response type accuracy measure must following formal arguments: learning.method learning method, used internally select correct prediction type type.measure accuracy type measure, used internally select correct prediction type

code: renoir(   filter,   npoints = 3,   ngrid,   nmin = round(nrow(x)/2),   looper = Looper(),   filename = "renoir",   outdir = NULL,   restore = TRUE,   learner,   evaluator,   logger,   hyperparameters,   x,   y,   weights = NULL,   offset = NULL,   resp.type,   rm.call = FALSE,   rm.fit = FALSE,   grouping = TRUE,   ... )

title: Evaluation of a learning method — renoir
text: filter Filter FilterList object npoints number sample sizes consider (.e. number training set sizes grid) ngrid (optional) grid sample sizes consider nmin minimum sample size (.e. number samples use training) looper Looper object filename (optional) name without extension output file outdir path output directory restore logical, whether try restore previously ran analysis stopped end (outdir set previous analysis) learner Learner object evaluator Evaluator object logger Logger object hyperparameters named list containing hyperparameters learning method tune x input matrix, rows observations columns variables. y response variable. number rows must match number rows x. weights (optional) vector observation weights offset vector containing offset, used linear models. Default NULL. resp.type response type rm.call logical, whether remove call models. Helpful object size expected big rm.fit logical, whether remove model fits used tuning hyperparameters . Helpful object size expected big object can huge. grouping logical, whether group results learning method, configuration, response type, sampling method ... arguments evaluate function

what: Significance analysis of microarrays - simple user interface — SAM.mod
title: Significance analysis of microarrays - simple user interface — SAM.mod
text: Modified SAM solve bug. Correlates large number features (eg genes) outcome variable, group indicator, quantitative variable survival time. simple user interface samr function applied array data. sequencing data applications, see function SAMseq

title: Significance analysis of microarrays - simple user interface — SAM.mod
code: SAM.mod(   x,   y = NULL,   censoring.status = NULL,   resp.type = c("Quantitative", "Two class unpaired", "Survival", "Multiclass",     "One class", "Two class paired", "Two class unpaired timecourse",     "One class timecourse", "Two class paired timecourse", "Pattern discovery"),   geneid = NULL,   genenames = NULL,   s0 = NULL,   s0.perc = NULL,   nperms = 100,   center.arrays = FALSE,   testStatistic = c("standard", "wilcoxon"),   time.summary.type = c("slope", "signed.area"),   regression.method = c("standard", "ranks"),   return.x = TRUE,   knn.neighbors = 10,   random.seed = NULL,   logged2 = FALSE,   fdr.output = 0.2,   eigengene.number = 1,   all.genes = FALSE )

title: Significance analysis of microarrays - simple user interface — SAM.mod
text: x Feature matrix: p (number features) n (number samples), one observation per column (missing values allowed) y n-vector outcome measurements censoring.status n-vector censoring censoring.status (1= died event occurred, 0=survived, event censored), needed censored survival outcome resp.type Problem type: "Quantitative" continuous parameter; "Two class unpaired";  "Survival" censored survival outcome;  "Multiclass": 2 groups;   "One class" single group;  "Two class paired" two classes paired observations; "Two class unpaired timecourse",  "One class time course", "Two class.paired timecourse", "Pattern discovery" geneid Optional character vector geneids output. genenames Optional character vector genenames output. s0 Exchangeability factor  denominator test statistic; Default automatic choice. used array data. s0.perc Percentile standard  deviation values use s0; default automatic choice; -1 means s0=0 (different s0.perc=0, meaning s0=zeroeth percentile  standard  deviation values= min sd values. used array data. nperms Number permutations used estimate false discovery rates center.arrays data sample (array) median centered outset? Default =FALSE. used array data. testStatistic Test statistic use two class unpaired case.Either "standard" (t-statistic) ,"wilcoxon" (Two-sample wilcoxon Mann-Whitney test). used array data. time.summary.type Summary measure time course: "slope", "signed.area"). used array data. regression.method Regression method quantitative case: "standard", (linear least squares) "ranks" (linear least squares  ranked data). used array data. return.x matrix feature values returned? useful time course data, x contains summaries features time. Otherwise x input data data\$x knn.neighbors Number nearest neighbors use imputation missing features values. used array data. random.seed Optional initial seed random number generator (integer) logged2 data transformed log (base 2)? information used  computing fold changes fdr.output (Approximate) False Discovery Rate cutoff output significant genes table eigengene.number Eigengene used  (just resp.type="Pattern discovery") .genes genes listed? Default FALSE

text: id scoring method name associated Scorer. scoring method one accuracy measures supported renoir, constructor automatically select scorer selector. See supported_scoring_methods() supported methods. scorer (optional) function evaluate model performance. Must provided id one accuracy measures supported renoir. scorer provided must conform renoir common interface, must following formal arguments: true vector (matrix) observed values. matrix provided, multi-response assumed pred vector (matrix) predicted values weights priors observations multi response multiple output values ... additional arguments can added parameters list containing parameters fix chosen scoring method resp.type (optional) response type. provided, selected id checked see available considered response type. grouped logical, whether compute separate statistics lists values provided selector (optional) function select optimal accuracy measure multiple values Must provided id one accuracy measures supported renoir. selector provided must conform renoir common interface, must following formal arguments: measures vector accuracy measures returned Scorer optimum optimisation problem solve selecting optimal accuracy measure multiple values quantifier Quantifier logger Logger

title: Scorer Class — Scorer-class

Two possible values min max quantifier Quantifier logger Logger

title: True Positive Rate — TPR
text: true positive rate measures ability classifier correctly predicting presence condition. defined $$sensitivity = recall = \textit{true positive rate} (TPR) = \frac{TP}{P} = \frac{TP}{TP + FN} = 1 - FNR$$ optimal value 1 worst value 0.

title: Absolute Error — absolute_error
text: true vector (matrix) observed values. matrix provided, multi-response assumed pred vector (matrix) predicted values weights observation weights. argument consistency, currently used. rweights response weights multi response multiple output values average errors multiple outputs averaged get single value observation sum errors multiple outputs summed get single value observation raw returns vector containing one error output

title: Absolute Error — absolute_error
text: absolute error, vector positive double values matrix, one column response, response multiple output values multi = "raw"

title: Absolute Error — absolute_error
text: absolute error (AE) based absolute values defined $$AE(y_{},\hat{y}_{}) = \lvert y_{} - \hat{y}_{} \rvert$$ \(y_{}\) true value \(\)-th sample \(\hat{y}_{}\) predicted value. observed data multiple output values weights provided, error weighted. $$wAE(w,y,\hat{y}) = \frac{1}{\sum_{j=1}^{n} w_{j}} w * \lvert y_{} - \hat{y}_{} \rvert$$ \(w_{j}\) weighting factor assigned \(j\)-th response. best possible score zero.

title: Absolute Error — absolute_error
text: Alessandro Barberis

title: Absolute Percentage Error — absolute_percentage_error
text: true vector (matrix) observed values. matrix provided, multi-response assumed pred vector (matrix) predicted values rweights response weights multi response multiple output values average errors multiple outputs averaged get single value observation sum errors multiple outputs summed get single value observation raw returns vector containing one error output

title: Absolute Percentage Error — absolute_percentage_error
text: absolute percentage error, vector positive double values matrix, one column response, response multiple output values multi = "raw"

title: Absolute Percentage Error — absolute_percentage_error
text: absolute percentage error (APE) based absolute values. absolute percentage error defined $$APE(y,\hat{y}) = \frac{\lvert y_{} - \hat{y}_{} \rvert}{\max{\lvert y_{} \rvert, \epsilon}}$$ \(y_{}\) true value \(\)-th sample, \(\hat{y}_{}\) predicted value, \(\epsilon\) arbitrary positive small number used avoid division zero. response multiple output values weights provided, error weighted. $$wAPE(w,y,\hat{y}) = \frac{w * \lvert y_{} - \hat{y}_{} \rvert}{\max{\lvert y_{} \rvert, \epsilon}}$$ \(w\) vector \(n\) elements, \(w_{j}\) weighting factor assigned \(j\)-th response. best possible score zero.

title: Absolute Percentage Error — absolute_percentage_error
text: Alessandro Barberis

title: Accuracy Classification Score — accuracy_score
text: accuracy measures fraction instances correctly categorized. defined : $$ACC = \frac{correct}{total} = \frac{TP + TN}{P + N} = \frac{TP + TN}{TP + FP + TN + FN} = 1 - ERR$$ optimal value 1 worst value 0. complementary statistic classification error rate.

Use normal population unknown mean known variance (n large), t population unknown mean variance n sample size, used compute degrees freedom distribution = "t"

title: Confidence Interval — ci
text: named numeric vector 2 elements, low , lower upper bounds confidence interval point estimate.

title: Confidence Interval — ci
text: confidence interval provides additional information variability point estimate generally defined $$CI = estimate \pm \textit{margin error} = estimate \pm \textit{critical value} \times \textit{standard error}$$ \(\textit{estimate}\) sample statistic estimating population parameter interest; \(\textit{critical value}\) value based sampling distribution estimate desired confidence level; \(\textit{standard error}\) standard deviation point estimate. Since estimates different samples population can different, estimate can seen random variable distribution. Given interested estimate specific sample rather want draw conclusions population, confidence interval can used obtain information population parameter. Beware interpretation. CI telling us population parameter inside range. fact, generally know population parameter, know interval contains . However, know certain number intervals (confidence level, e.g. 95\ formed way contain parameter.

title: Compute the significance of the filtering test — ebayes_screener
text: x input matrix, rows observations columns variables. y response variable. number rows must match number rows x. weights priors observations resp.type response type observations (optional) indices observations keep logged2 whether data logged 2. method fitting method; "ls" least squares "robust" robust regression design design matrix microarray experiment, rows corresponding samples columns coefficients estimated.   Defaults object$design non-NULL, otherwise unit vector meaning samples treated replicates single treatment group. contrasts numeric matrix rows corresponding coefficients fit columns containing contrasts. May vector one contrast. NAs allowed. assay.type Assay type: "array" microarray data, "seq" sequencing data proportion numeric value 0 1, assumed proportion genes differentially expressed coef (optional) integer indicating response variable consider multi-response data multi = "raw" number maximum number genes list adjust.method method used adjust p-values multiple testing. Options, increasing conservatism, include "none", "BH", "" "holm" p.value cutoff value adjusted p-values. genes lower p-values listed. top.table.sort.character string specifying statistic rank genes . Possible values topTable "logFC", "AveExpr", "t", "P", "p", "B" "none". (Permitted synonyms "M" "logFC", "" "Amean" "AveExpr", "T" "t" "p" "P".) multi response multiple output values max max value scores across multiple outputs selected get single value observation average scores multiple outputs averaged get single value observation sum scores multiple outputs summed get single value observation raw returns scores multiple outputs logger Logger ... arguments

title: F1 Score — f1_score
text: F1 score measure accuracy computed harmonic mean precision recall: $$F_{1} = \frac{2}{precision^{-1} + recall^{-1}} = 2\frac{precision \times recall}{precision + recall} = \frac{TP}{TP + \frac{1}{2}(FP + FN)}$$ highest possible value 1.0, indicating perfect precision recall. lowest possible value 0. specific case F-beta score, beta = 1

title: F-beta Score — fbeta_score
text: F-beta score measure accuracy based precision recall. defined $$F_{\beta} = (1 + \beta^{2}) \frac{precision \times recall}{(\beta^{2} precision) + recall} = (1 + \beta^{2}) \frac{TP}{(1 + \beta^{2})TP + \beta^{2} FN + FP)}$$ highest possible value F-score 1.0, indicating perfect precision recall. lowest possible value 0.

text: object list renoir.tat objects best.config configuration consider recruitment.term whether use binary variable (presence = 0 presence = 1) multiplied sign coefficient, use directly coefficient feature computation significance score. set set data used computation accuracy measures. example, set = "test.set" accuracy measures used computation features importance ones calculated test set.

title: Features Importance — features_importance
text: single response, list vectors, vector associate accuracy measure, contains measures significance feature. multi-response, list lists.

title: Features Importance — features_importance
text: feature significance score computed sum normalised coefficient feature model multiplied weight model. formula -th feature : $$score_{} = \frac{1}{s}\sum_{j=1}^{n} weight_{j}*coefficient_{j} ,$$ \(n\) total number models computed across different training set sizes, \(coefficient_{j}\) normalised coefficient (.e. coefficient feature divided maximum absolute value coefficients features model value ranging \([-1,1]\)), \(s\) sum weights. \(weight\) model obtained dividing multiplicative inverse squared prediction error model max value across models, models better prediction accuracy higher weight: $$weight_{j} = \frac{w_{j}}{w_{best}},$$ \(w_{j}\) multiplicative inverse squared prediction error model: $$w_{j} = \frac{1}{err_{j}^2},$$ $$w_{best} = \max{w_{1},...,w_{j},...,w_{n}}.$$ Note auc accuracy measure, consider prediction error \(err_{j} = 1 - auc_{j}\). selecting use = "presence", \(coefficient_{j}\) term computation significance score exchanged \(presence_{j}*sign_{j}\), \(presence_{j}\) stands presence feature j-th model \(sign_{j}\) sign coefficient -th feature j-th model.

title: Linear model for series of arrays — limma
text: x matrix-like data object containing log-ratios log-expression values series arrays, rows corresponding genes columns samples. design design matrix microarray experiment, rows corresponding arrays columns coefficients estimated. Defaults unit vector meaning arrays treated replicates. method fitting method; "ls" least squares "robust" robust regression contrasts numeric matrix rows corresponding coefficients fit columns containing contrasts. May vector one contrast. assay.type Assay type: "array" microarray data, "seq" sequencing data proportion numeric value 0 1, assumed proportion genes differentially expressed coef column number column name specifying coefficient contrast linear model interest. topTable, can also vector column subscripts, case gene ranking F-statistic set contrasts. coef single value, moderated t-statistics p-values coefficient contrast used. coef takes two values, moderated F-statistics set coefficients contrasts used. coef left NULL, coefficients contrasts fitted model used, except coefficient named (Intercept) removed. number maximum number genes list adjust.method method used adjust p-values multiple testing. Options, increasing conservatism, include "none", "BH", "" "holm" p.value cutoff value adjusted p-value top.table.sort.character string specifying statistic rank genes . Possible values topTable "logFC", "AveExpr", "t", "P", "p", "B" "none". (Permitted synonyms "M" "logFC", "" "Amean" "AveExpr", "T" "t" "p" "P".) plotVenn logical, whether plot Venn diagram showing numbers genes signifcant comparison outdir output directory logger Logger warningsFile path warning file use. logFile path log file use.

code: mean_absolute_error(   true,   pred,   weights = NULL,   multi = c("average", "sum", "raw"),   rweights = NULL )

title: Mean Absolute Error — mean_absolute_error
text: true vector (matrix) observed values. matrix provided, multi-response assumed pred vector (matrix) predicted values weights observation weights multi response multiple output values average errors multiple outputs averaged get single value observation sum errors multiple outputs summed get single value observation raw returns vector containing one error output rweights response weights

title: Mean Absolute Error — mean_absolute_error
text: mean absolute error, positive double vector positive double values, one response, response multiple output values multi = "raw"

title: Mean Absolute Error — mean_absolute_error
text: mean absolute error (MAE) measure errors based absolute values. treats small large errors equally less sensitive outliers compared measures (e.g. MSE). MAE estimated n observations defined $$MAE(y,\hat{y}) = \frac{1}{n}\sum_{=1}^{n} \lvert y_{} - \hat{y}_{} \rvert$$ \(y_{}\) true value \(\)-th sample \(\hat{y}_{}\) predicted value. observation weights provided, weighted mean absolute error computed $$wMAE(w,y,\hat{y}) = \frac{1}{\sum_{=1}^{n} w_{}}\sum_{=1}^{n} w_{} * \lvert y_{} - \hat{y}_{} \rvert$$ \(w_{}\) weighting factor assigned \(\)-th observation. best possible score zero.

title: Mean Absolute Error — mean_absolute_error
text: Alessandro Barberis

title: Mean Absolute Percentage Error — mean_absolute_percentage_error
code: mean_absolute_percentage_error(   true,   pred,   weights = NULL,   multi = c("average", "sum", "raw"),   eps = 1e-10,   rweights = NULL )

title: Mean Absolute Percentage Error — mean_absolute_percentage_error
text: true vector (matrix) observed values. matrix provided, multi-response assumed pred vector (matrix) predicted values weights observation weights multi response multiple output values average errors multiple outputs averaged get single value observation sum errors multiple outputs summed get single value observation raw returns vector containing one error output eps arbitrary positive small number, used correct MAPE formula avoid division zero rweights response weights

title: Mean Absolute Percentage Error — mean_absolute_percentage_error
text: mean absolute percentage error, positive double vector positive double values, one response, response multiple output values multi = "raw"

title: Mean Absolute Percentage Error — mean_absolute_percentage_error
text: mean absolute percentage error (MAPE) measure errors based relative absolute values. MAPE estimated n observations defined $$MAPE(y,\hat{y}) = \frac{1}{n}\sum_{=1}^{n} \frac{\lvert y_{} - \hat{y}_{} \rvert}{\max{\lvert y_{} \rvert, \epsilon}}$$ \(y_{}\) true value \(\)-th sample, \(\hat{y}_{}\) predicted value, \(\epsilon\) arbitrary positive small number used avoid division zero. observation weights provided, weighted mean absolute percentage error computed $$wMAPE(w,y,\hat{y}) = \frac{1}{\sum_{=1}^{n} w_{}}\sum_{=1}^{n} w_{} * \frac{\lvert y_{} - \hat{y}_{} \rvert}{\max{\lvert y_{} \rvert, \epsilon}}$$ \(w_{}\) weighting factor assigned \(\)-th observation. best possible score zero.

title: Mean Absolute Percentage Error — mean_absolute_percentage_error
text: Alessandro Barberis

title: Mean Squared Error — mean_squared_error
text: true vector (matrix) observed values. matrix provided, multi-response assumed pred vector (matrix) predicted values weights observation weights multi response multiple output values average errors multiple outputs averaged get single value observation sum errors multiple outputs summed get single value observation raw returns vector containing one error output root logical, whether return MSE root mean squared error (RMSE) rweights response weights

title: Mean Squared Error — mean_squared_error
text: mean squared error, positive double vector positive double values, one response, response multiple output values multi = "raw"

title: Mean Squared Error — mean_squared_error
text: mean squared error (MSE) measure errors based squared losses. Small large errors treated equally, large errors heavily weighted small ones thus skewing measure. sensitive outliers compared measures (e.g. MAE). MSE estimated n observations defined $$MSE(y,\hat{y}) = \frac{1}{n}\sum_{=1}^{n} (y_{} - \hat{y}_{})^{2}$$ \(y_{}\) true value \(\)-th sample \(\hat{y}_{}\) predicted value. observation weights provided, weighted mean absolute error computed $$wMSE(w,y,\hat{y}) = \frac{1}{\sum_{=1}^{n} w_{}}\sum_{=1}^{n} w_{} * (y_{} - \hat{y}_{})^{2}$$ \(w_{}\) weighting factor assigned \(\)-th observation. best possible score zero.

title: Mean Squared Error — mean_squared_error
text: Alessandro Barberis

title: Mean Squared Logarithmic Error — mean_squared_log_error
text: mean squared logarithmic error (MSLE) measure errors based squared logarithmic losses. metric commonly preferred (e.g. MSE) -predicted estimates penalised -predicted ones. Huge differences predicted true values penalised (huge numbers). MSLE estimated n observations defined $$MSLE(y,\hat{y}) = \frac{1}{n}\sum_{=1}^{n} (log(1 + y_{}) - log(1 + \hat{y}_{}))^{2}$$ \(log\) natural logarithm, \(y_{}\) true value \(\)-th sample \(\hat{y}_{}\) predicted value. observation weights provided, weighted mean absolute error computed $$wMSLE(w,y,\hat{y}) = \frac{1}{\sum_{=1}^{n} w_{}}\sum_{=1}^{n} w_{} * (log(1 + y_{}) - log(1 + \hat{y}_{}))^{2}$$ \(w_{}\) weighting factor assigned \(\)-th observation. best possible score zero.

title: Mean Squared Logarithmic Error — mean_squared_log_error
text: Alessandro Barberis

text: x input matrix, rows observations columns variables. y response variable. number rows must match number rows x. weights priors observations resp.type response type observations (optional) indices observations keep coef (optional) integer indicating response variable consider multi-response data multi = "raw" sam.resp.type Problem type: "Quantitative" continuous parameter (Available array sequencing data) "Two class unpaired" array sequencing data "Survival" censored survival outcome (array sequencing data) "Multiclass" 2 groups (array sequencing data) "One class" single group (array data) "Two class paired" two classes paired observations (array sequencing data) "Two class unpaired timecourse" array data "One class time course" array data "Two class.paired timecourse" array data "Pattern discovery" array data geneid Optional character vector geneids output. genenames Optional character vector genenames output. s0 Exchangeability factor  denominator test statistic; Default automatic choice. used array data. s0.perc Percentile standard  deviation values use s0; default automatic choice; -1 means s0=0 (different s0.perc=0, meaning s0=zeroeth percentile  standard  deviation values= min sd values. used array data. nperms Number permutations used estimate false discovery rates center.arrays data sample (array) median centered outset? Default =FALSE. used array data. testStatistic Test statistic use two class unpaired case.Either "standard" (t-statistic) ,"wilcoxon" (Two-sample wilcoxon Mann-Whitney test). used array data. time.summary.type Summary measure time course: "slope", "signed.area"). used array data. regression.method Regression method quantitative case: "standard", (linear least squares) "ranks" (linear least squares  ranked data). used array data. return.x matrix feature values returned? useful time course data, x contains summaries features time. Otherwise x input data data\$x knn.neighbors Number nearest neighbors use imputation missing features values. used array data. random.seed Optional initial seed random number generator (integer) logged2 data transformed log (base 2)? information used  computing fold changes fdr.output (Approximate) False Discovery Rate cutoff output significant genes table eigengene.number Eigengene used  (just resp.type="Pattern discovery") nresamp Number resamples used construct test statistic. Default 20. return.type debug argument, object output samr reported logger Logger multi response multiple output values max max value scores across multiple outputs selected get single value observation average scores multiple outputs averaged get single value observation sum scores multiple outputs summed get single value observation raw returns scores multiple outputs ... arguments

title: R squared — r2_score
text: true vector (matrix) observed values. matrix provided, multi-response assumed pred vector (matrix) predicted values weights observation weights multi response multiple output values average errors multiple outputs averaged get single value observation sum errors multiple outputs summed get single value observation raw returns vector containing one error output

title: R squared — r2_score
text: R squared score, double vector double values, one response, response multiple output values multi = "raw"

title: R squared — r2_score
text: coefficient determination (R squared) measure proportion variance dependent variable explained independent variables. R2 estimated n observations defined $$R^{2}(y,\hat{y}) = 1 - \frac{\sum_{=1}^{n} (y_{} - \hat{y}_{})^{2}}{\sum_{=1}^{n} (y_{} - \bar{y})^{2}}$$ \(\bar{y}\) mean observed data, \(y_{}\) true value \(\)-th sample, \(\hat{y}_{}\) predicted value. observation weights provided, weighted R squared computed $$wR^{2}(w,y,\hat{y}) = 1 - \frac{\sum_{=1}^{n} w_{}*(y_{} - \hat{y}_{})^{2}}{\sum_{=1}^{n} w_{}*(y_{} - \bar{y})^{2}}$$ \(w_{}\) weighting factor assigned \(\)-th observation. best possible score one.

title: R squared — r2_score
text: Alessandro Barberis

title: Root-Mean-Square Error — root_mean_squared_error
text: root-mean-square error (RMSE) measure errors based squared losses. defined squared root mean_squared_error: $$RMSE(y,\hat{y}) = \sqrt{MSE(y,\hat{y})} = \sqrt{\frac{1}{n}\sum_{=1}^{n} (y_{} - \hat{y}_{})^{2}}$$ observation weights provided, weighted root mean squared error computed $$wRMSE(w,y,\hat{y}) = \sqrt{wMSE(w,y,\hat{y})} = \sqrt{\frac{1}{\sum_{=1}^{n} w_{}}\sum_{=1}^{n} w_{} * (y_{} - \hat{y}_{})^{2}}$$ function shortcut mean_squared_error(root = TRUE, ...).

title: Root-Mean-Square Error — root_mean_squared_error
text: Alessandro Barberis

code: sam(   x,   y = NULL,   censoring.status = NULL,   resp.type = c("Quantitative", "Two class unpaired", "Survival", "Multiclass",     "One class", "Two class paired", "Two class unpaired timecourse",     "One class timecourse", "Two class paired timecourse", "Pattern discovery"),   geneid = NULL,   genenames = NULL,   assay.type = c("array", "seq"),   s0 = 1e-04,   s0.perc = NULL,   nperms = 100,   center.arrays = FALSE,   testStatistic = c("standard", "wilcoxon"),   time.summary.type = c("slope", "signed.area"),   regression.method = c("standard", "ranks"),   return.x = FALSE,   knn.neighbors = 10,   random.seed = NULL,   logged2 = FALSE,   fdr.output = 0.2,   eigengene.number = 1,   nresamp = 20,   plotSam = FALSE,   verbose = FALSE,   outdir = NULL,   logger = Logger(),   all.genes = FALSE )

title: Significance analysis of microarrays (wrapper function to SAM) — sam
text: x Feature matrix: p (number features) n (number samples), one observation per column (missing values allowed) y n-vector outcome measurements censoring.status n-vector censoring censoring.status (1=died event occurred, 0=survived, event censored), needed censored survival outcome resp.type Problem type: "Quantitative" continuous parameter (Available array sequencing data) "Two class unpaired" array sequencing data "Survival" censored survival outcome (array sequencing data) "Multiclass" 2 groups (array sequencing data) "One class" single group (array data) "Two class paired" two classes paired observations (array sequencing data) "Two class unpaired timecourse" array data "One class time course" array data "Two class.paired timecourse" array data "Pattern discovery" array data geneid Optional character vector geneids output. genenames Optional character vector genenames output. assay.type Assay type: "array" microarray data, "seq" counts sequencing s0 Exchangeability factor denominator test statistic; Default original function automatic choice. used array data. default small number since sometimes automatic choice get weird results. s0.perc Percentile standard deviation values use s0; default automatic choice; -1 means s0=0 (different s0.perc=0, meaning s0=zeroeth percentile standard deviation values= min sd values. used array data. nperms Number permutations used estimate false discovery rates center.arrays data sample (array) median centered outset? Default =FALSE. used array data. testStatistic Test statistic use two class unpaired case. Either "standard" (t-statistic) ,"wilcoxon" (Two-sample wilcoxon Mann-Whitney test). used array data. time.summary.type Summary measure time course: "slope", "signed.area"). used array data. return.x = matrix feature values returned? useful time course data, x contains summaries features time. Otherwise x input data data\$x knn.neighbors Number nearest neighbors use imputation missing features values. used array data. random.seed Optional initial seed random number generator (integer) logged2 data transformed log (base 2)? information used computing fold changes fdr.output (Approximate) False Discovery Rate cutoff output significant genes table eigengene.number Eigengene used (just resp.type="Pattern discovery") plotSam whether make Q-Q plot SAM analysis, default TRUE. outdir output directory logger Logger .genes genes listed? Default FALSE nresapm assay.type="seq", number resamples used construct test statistic. Default 20. used sequencing data. Default equal nresamp must nresamp. used sequencing data

title: Sensitivity — sensitivity
text: sensitivity measures ability classifier correctly predicting presence condition. defined $$sensitivity = recall = \textit{true positive rate} (TPR) = \frac{TP}{P} = \frac{TP}{TP + FN} = 1 - FNR$$ optimal value 1 worst value 0.

title: Jaccard Score — threat_score
text: true vector (matrix) observed values. matrix provided, multi-response assumed pred vector (matrix) predicted values weights observation weights (implemented yet) multi response multiple output values average errors multiple outputs averaged get single value observation micro score computed using global number true positives, false negatives false positives macro scores different classes averaged unweighted mean get single value. Class imbalance taken account weighted scores different classes averaged weighted mean get single value. Weights number true instances per class. takes account label imbalance raw returns vector containing one score class binary returns score class specified positive ... arguments multiresponse_classification_metric

what: Unbiased Variance of the Weighted Mean — uevarwm
title: Unbiased Variance of the Weighted Mean — uevarwm
text: Computes unbiased estimate variance weighted sample mean.

title: Unbiased Variance of the Weighted Mean — uevarwm
code: uevarwm(x, weights, na.rm = T)

title: Unbiased Variance of the Weighted Mean — uevarwm
text: x vector measurements weights vector weights na.rm logical, whether NA values x stripped computation proceeds

title: Unbiased Variance of the Weighted Mean — uevarwm
text: length-one numeric vector.

title: Unbiased Variance of the Weighted Mean — uevarwm
text: Currently, implementation considering eventual stratification estimate variance. also assume measurements (.e. x) drawn population variance \(V(x_{}) = \sigma_{x}^2\). variance sample mean computed $$\hat{\sigma}_{W}^{2} = V(\frac{\sum_{=1}^{n} w_{}x_{}}{\sum_{=1}^{n} w_{}}) = \frac{1}{(\sum_{=1}^{n} w_{})^2} V(\sum_{=1}^{n} w_{}x_{}) = \frac{\sum_{=1}^{n} w_{}^2}{(\sum_{=1}^{n} w_{})^2} \sigma_{x}^2$$ different ways estimate variance x (\(\sigma_{x}^2\)). use common formula unbiased estimator unweighted data $$s_{x}^2 = \frac{\sum_{=1}^{n} (x_{} - \bar{x})^2}{n - 1}$$

title: Unbiased Variance of the Weighted Mean — uevarwm
text: Alessandro Barberis
